data.title: ui.timer seems to bug while trying to instantiate multiple classes?
data.body:
I've boiled the example code here:

script.rpy:
http://pastebin.com/pTV0rEK2

This is a script that calls two functions from `ui.timer`, who each print to console, then calls two classes from ui.timer, who should each print to console.

What should be printed (as you go along in the script), is

```
Function One!
Function Two!
Class One!
Class Two!
```

What i get instead is

```
Function One!
Function Two!
Class One!
```

This is when I run it using Ren'Py 6.18.3.761.

More specifically, it seems that after the first class is instantiated, other calls to `ui.timer` seem to bug out, as calling

```
test_classes()
test_functions()
```

 (see pastebin for functions)
only prints
`Class One!`
and apparently causes ui.timer to only instantiate the very first class

data.title: loadsve.py shutil.copy permission bit issue
data.body:
I'd like to point out an issue when playing renpy based games on nfs mounts:

> File "/media/nfs/Spiele/SteamLibraryLinux/steamapps/common/Sunrider/renpy/loadsave.py", line 219, in write_file
> shutil.copy(self.first_filename, filename_new)
> File "/home/tom/ab/x64lucid-deps/install/lib/python2.7/shutil.py", line 118, in copy
> File "/home/tom/ab/x64lucid-deps/install/lib/python2.7/shutil.py", line 91, in copymode
> OSError: [Errno 1] Operation not permitted: '/media/nfs/Spiele/SteamLibraryLinux/steamapps/common/Sunrider/game/saves/1-4-LT1.save.new'

As you can see I've mounted the data via nfs - my server restricted the permissions so that you cannot change userrights/permissions.

shutil.copy is specified to copy permission bits

So the easy fix is to juse use "shutil.copyfile" instead of "shutil.copy".
I confirm it working changing that.

data.title: 3D camera motion functions and Position Viewer
data.body:
I added Ren'Py 3D camera functions and a gui viewer.
sample  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XYaVrwpcKkE

With some limitations, those functions allow Ren'Py to simulate 3D camera motion. This will easily
let you achieve a parallax effect by placing sprites and assets on a 3D field.
Those applies transforms to each layers which are registered as 3D layer by
positions of a camera and 3D layers on a 3D field to simulate 3D camera motion.

```
def register_3d_layer(*layers):
    """
     :doc: camera

     Register layers as 3D layers. 3D layers is applied transforms to by
     positions of a camera and 3D layers. You can use this in game again
     and again.

     `layers`
          This should be the string or strings of a layer name.
     """

def camera_reset():
    """
     :doc: camera

     Reset a camera and 3D layers positions.
     """

def camera_move(x, y, z, rotate=0, duration=0, warper='linear', subpixel=True, loop=False):
    """
     :doc: camera

     Move the coordinate and rotate of a camera and apply transforms to all 3D layers.

     `x`
          the x coordinate of a camera
     `y`
          the y coordinate of a camera
     `z`
          the z coordinate of a camera
     `rotate`
          Defaul 0, the rotate of a camera
     `duration`
          Default 0, this is the second times taken to move a camera.
     `warper`
          Default 'linear', this should be string and the name of a warper
          registered with ATL.
     `subpixel`
          Default True, if True, causes things to be drawn on the screen
          using subpixel positioning
     `loop`
          Default False, if True, this motion repeats.
     """

def layer_move(layer, z, duration=0, warper='linear', subpixel=True, loop=False):
    """
     :doc: camera

     Move the z coordinate of a layer and apply transform to the layer.

     `layer`
          the string of a layer name to be moved
     `z`
          the z coordinate of a layer
     `duration`
          Default 0, this is the second times taken to move a camera.
     `warper`
          Default 'linear', this should be the string of the name of a
          warper registered with ATL.
     `subpixel`
          Default True, if True, causes things to be drawn on the screen
          using subpixel positioning
     `loop`
          Default False, if True, this motion repeats.
     """

def camera_moves(check_points, warper='linear', loop=False, subpixel=True):
    """
     :doc: camera

     Move a camera through check points and apply transforms to all 3D
     layers.

     `check_points`
          tuples of x, y, z, rotate, duration
     `loop`
          Default False, if True, this sequence of motions repeats.
     `subpixel`
          Default True, if True, causes things to be drawn on the screen
          using subpixel positioning
     """
def layer_moves(layer, check_points, warper='linear', loop=False, subpixel=True):
    """
     :doc: camera

     Move a layer through check points and apply transform to the layer.

     `layer`
          the string of a layer name to be moved
     `check_points`
          tuples of z, duration
     `loop`
          Default False, if True, this sequence of motions repeats.
     `subpixel`
          Default True, if True, causes things to be drawn on the screen
          using subpixel positioning
     """
```

If you use this feature, in the first, set additional layers to be
registered as 3D layer.

For example, Write a code like below in options.rpy and add 'background', 'middle', 'forward'  layers.::

```
    config.layers = ['master', 'background', 'middle', 'forward', 'transient', 'screens', 'overlay']
```

Second, register layers which participate to a 3D motion as 3d layers by :func:`register_3d_layer`::

```
    init python:
        register_3d_layer('background', 'middle', 'forward')
```

Then, a camera and layers can move. ::

```
     label start:
         # reset a camera and layers positions
         $ camera_reset()
         scene bg onlayer background
         show A onlayer middle
         show B onlayer forward
         # It takes 0 second to move layers
         $ layer_move("background", 2000)
         $ layer_move("middle", 1500)
         $ layer_move("forward", 1000)
         with dissolve
         'It takes 1 second to move a camera to (1800, 0, 0)'
         $ camera_move(1800, 0, 0, 0, 1)
         'It takes 5 seconds to move a camera to (0, 0, 1600)'
         $ camera_move(0, 0, 1600, 0, 5)
         'A camera moves to (0, 0, 0) at the moment'
         $ camera_move(0, 0, 0)
         'It takes 1 second to rotate a camera to 180 degrees'
         $ camera_move(0, 0, 0, 180, 1)
         'It takes 1 second to rotate a camera to -180 degrees and 0.5 second to move a camera to (-1800, 0, 500)'
         $ camera_moves( ( (0, 0, 0, 0, 1), (-1800, 0, 500, 0, 1.5) ) )
         'a camera shuttles between (-1800, 0, 500) and (0, 0, 0)'
         $ camera_moves( ( (0, 0, 0, 0, .5), (-1800, 0, 500, 0, 1) ), loop=True)
```

When :var:`config.developer` is True, pressing position_viewer (by default,
"shift+P"), will open Position Viewer. This allow you to adjustment a camera
,3D layers and images positions by bars and manual inputs and see the result at
the moment.

Notice that 3D camera motion has some limits.:
- 3D camera motion applies transforms to 3D layers, so the show layer statement or
  :func:`renpy.show_layer_at` to 3D layers can't be usable.
- z coordinates of 3D layers don't affect the stacking order of 3d layers.
- A camera and a layer can't move at the same time.

data.title: Allow rpy files to fully support indentation with spaces and tabs.
data.body:
This is 100% backwards compatible with all existing rpy files that use
spaces. Therefore, this does not require any change to anybody's
existing code. It only adds a new feature, allowing those who wish to
use tabs for indentation in rpy files to do so.

Previously, rpy files completely rejected indentation with tabs, and
forced all users to use spaces for indentation. Now, future rpy files
can be created using either tabs or spaces for indentation, at the
user's discretion.

To be sure that tabs and spaces are never mixed in a confusing manner,
this code forces all indentation to have the same prefix. Tabs are never
considered to be equivalent to any number of spaces. This matches what
we'd expect from files indented using best practices, with either spaces
only or tabs only, and eliminates any accidental "compatibility" between
the two in the same block.

data.title: Ren'py slow as a turtle when using package from ubuntu repos
data.body:
Hello,
when using the 6.15.7 packages from Ubuntu, renpy is incredibly slow. The animations are skippy, and music does not play back at all. On top of that, I can not start the demo from the launcher but have to do so from my ubuntu menu.
 I'm using an Asus x550cc with lubuntu Trusty 14.04 on it. When I download the newer version (6.18) and just execute it from there everything works fine. I read about earlier ubuntu packages of ren'py being corrupt, maybe those are as well?

data.title: Windows Launch Improvements
data.body:
Right now, renpy.exe executes lib/windows-i686/renpy.exe -EO renpy.py to start the game. It would be better if renpy.exe ran lib/windows-i696/renpy.exe without any arguments, and the latter script would set up the environment and run python directly.

After making this change, we'd be able to pin Ren'Py to the windows taskbar, among other improvements.

data.title: Excessive memory usage in im.py
data.body: Texture preloading at https://github.com/renpy/renpy/blob/master/renpy/display/im.py#L225 means that if there's a chain used somewhere like Image (1920x1080) -> Scale (320x180) -> Recolor -> Composite, each of these intermediate images, including the first big one will create textures, which is neither required, nor acceptable on mobile devices.

data.title: Add clipbord functions
data.body:
```
    def put_clipboard(string):
        """
        :doc: other

        Put a string to clipboard and return True. If this fails, return None.
        """

    def get_clipboard():
        """
        :doc: other

        Get a string from clipboard and return it. If this fails, return None.
        """
```

However, if there are no saved games (for example, when the game is run for the first time), this function crashes.  I believe it should return "None" instead, as the function documentation states.

data.title: Please allow additional arguments to "function" in Transform class
data.body:
Now, Transform class takes a "function" argument and this is called with three arguments.

Please allow additional arguments to "function",
For example, keyword arguments beginning with "_" to Transform class have the prefix stripped off, and are passed to the "funciton" as arguments.

example

```
    def test(tran, st, at, x, y):
            return None
    Transform(function=test, _x=x, _y=y)
```

First, I tried to use inner functions, but inner functions isn't saved.
I want to use flexible transforms.

By the way, do you have a plan to add ATL "if" statements?

data.title: Please allow additional arguments to "function" in Transform
"function" in Transform class is called even after "function" returned None.
data.body:
According to the document, if "function" taken by Transform class returns None, this "function" is never called again.
But this "function" is called even after this returned None.

I used below code.

```
    init python:
        def function(tran, st, at):
            persistent.test=st
            if st <= 1:
                return .005
            else:
                return None

    label start:
        $renpy.show_layer_at(Transform(function=function, "master"))
        "[persistent.test]"
        "[persistent.test]"
        "[persistent.test]"
        "[persistent.test]"
        "[persistent.test]"
        "[persistent.test]"
        "[persistent.test]"
```

This is bug?
